ArticleTitle.sentence: A new orphan member of the nuclear hormone receptor superfamily closely related to Rev-Erb.

AbstractText.sentence: We have isolated complementary DNA clones encoding a novel orphan member of the nuclear receptor superfamily, termed BD73.

event.clue: We have isolated complementary DNA clones encoding a novel orphan member of the nuclear receptor superfamily, termed BD73.

AbstractText.sentence: This protein shows strong amino acid sequence similarity to the previously described Rev-ErbA alpha.

Unlike Rev-Erb, in which the opposite strand of the C-terminal coding region encodes the C-terminal portion of a variant thyroid hormone receptor isoform, the opposite strand of the C-terminal coding region of BD73 does not have any extensive open reading frames.

event.clue: Unlike Rev-Erb, in which the opposite strand of the C-terminal coding region encodes the C-terminal portion of a variant thyroid hormone receptor isoform, the opposite strand of the C-terminal coding region of BD73 does not have any extensive open reading frames.

AbstractText.sentence: BD73 messenger RNA is expressed in a wide variety of tissues and cell lines.

event.clue: BD73 messenger RNA is expressed in a wide variety of tissues and cell lines.

AbstractText.sentence: In quiescent HepG2 cells, BD73 messenger RNA levels are strongly induced by planar aromatic antioxidants.

event.clue: In quiescent HepG2 cells, BD73 messenger RNA levels are strongly induced by planar aromatic antioxidants.

AbstractText.sentence: Like Rev-Erb, BD73 binds as a monomer to a DNA sequence which consists of a specific A/T-rich sequence upstream of the consensus hexameric half-site specified by the P box of the DNA-binding domain.

event.clue: Like Rev-Erb, BD73 binds as a monomer to a DNA sequence which consists of a specific A/T-rich sequence upstream of the consensus hexameric half-site specified by the P box of the DNA-binding domain.

AbstractText.sentence: Amino acid sequence comparisons suggest that the A box sequence, which has been suggested to mediate monomer binding by other superfamily members, lies closer to the DNA-binding domain in BD73 and Rev-Erb than in other receptors.
Under the conditions examined, neither BD73 nor Rev-Erb activated reporters containing multiple copies of their common binding site.

event.clue: Under the conditions examined, neither BD73 nor Rev-Erb activated reporters containing multiple copies of their common binding site.

AbstractText.sentence: Thus, these two orphans may require an as yet unidentified ligand or other signal for such activation.

event.clue: Thus, these two orphans may require an as yet unidentified ligand or other signal for such activation.

AbstractText.sentence: Together, BD73 and Rev-Erb define a subgroup of orphan receptors that bind as monomers to a half-site flanked by a specific and extended A/T-rich sequence.

event.clue: Together, BD73 and Rev-Erb define a subgroup of orphan receptors that bind as monomers to a half-site flanked by a specific and extended A/T-rich sequence.
